text:
*[Bug 18950] CMake recipe GdalConfig is faulty*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18950>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. I've fixed this in a development version of Rtools, the
cmake files are patched to avoid full paths. To appear in the upcoming Rtools45
update.

The paths you found are not relative, they are absolute (but indeed, still
wrong). In addition to the problem you found in GDAL-targets.cmake, there was a
problem in the NetCDF targets file as well, that brought in the full path to
hdf5_hl.a. Thanks for providing a reproducible example that made this easier to
debug.

I've also added patching of other cmake targets files that included the wrong
paths (both "valid" full msys2 paths, which however don't work with cmake, as
well as full path not valid after Rtools is installed).

I've not tried to trace this up to the original place where the incorrect paths
are generated, I can't allocate time for that, and in the cases when I tried
this in the past, it actually was quite hard. If you have the energy to trace
that and propose fixes to the upstream projects, that would of course be highly
appreciated.

A broader context is that pre-compiled libraries, which are part of Rtools, are
cross-compiled using (slightly modified) MXE on Linux. Therefore, paths also in
cmake files are absolute paths on that Unix system. Cmake has documented
approaches how to create paths that are relocatable, and when that is used
correctly, absolute paths are re-computed/re-adjusted on the target system.
Some software doesn't do this or doesn't do this correctly or doesn't do this
for all libraries correctly (and probably it is not tested).

Another difference from Msys2 is that MXE/Rtools use static libraries. Again,
external software is sometimes not maintained well for static libraries. It may
not be necessarily related to the problems reported here, but it might be, as
there are more dependencies to compute when using static libraries, and other
cmake code paths may be taken.

So it is not surprising that some cmake files don't work in MXE/Rtools but work
in Msys2.

Pkg-config files have similar problems and are also being fixed when building
Rtools. But they are more tested as it is the primary way of finding
configuration in MXE itself (yet, again, not exclusive, some software uses
cmake).

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

text:
*[Bug 17839] `R_GetCurrentEnv()` always returns the base namespace*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17839>

--- Comment #8 from Luke Tierney (<mailto:luke@stat.uiowa.edu|luke@stat.uiowa.edu>) ---
I have changed `R_GetCurrentEnv` in r88921 to use the closure environment of
the top closure call on the context stack, or `R_GlobalEnv` if there is none.
For now I have marked this function as in the experimental API, but I am still
not convinced that it is necessary or worth the maintenance effort, so it might
get removed.

*[Bug 18681] [.POSIXlt sets "balanced" attribute wrongly*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18681>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|REOPENED                    |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #12 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Indeed.  There *is* another similar case, in the `length<-` method, the case
where the object is made longer, fortunately revealed by our own tests.
Hence, I've fixed that analogously.

This now seems fine to me, and hence I've committed the (updated!) patch and
tests to R-devel in  svn 88923.

(Depending on CRAN feedback, it may go into the pre-releases of R 4.5.2 ..)

text:
*[Bug 18958] 'methods_message' component of 'check_packages_used' internal class should be character(), not "", when empty*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18958>

--- Comment #1 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
Created attachment 3557
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3557&action=edit>
Change methods-message to character(), not ""

(hit submit by mistake on the original issue)

A minor thing, but using `""` instead of `character()` prevents us from doing
nice code like

```
...

report <- .check_packages_used(...)
if (!any(lengths(report)) {
  return(...)
}
...
```

We can see that in the patch -- in `format.check_packages_used`, all the other
components use an `if (xx <- length(x$...))` check whereas we have `if
(nzchar(x$methods_message))`. (in fact, we could simplify a bit further and
drop the `if()` since `c(..., character())` will just drop the empty input, but
I left it as is to keep the parallel structure).

PS for purely internal, minor things like this, I'm still not sure the
preferred way to report among (1) discuss first on r-devel [way too high
barrier for an internal change IMO] (2) file on Bugzilla [might give the
impression this is a "bug" when strictly speaking nothing's "broken"] (3) reach
out to a single R-core member responsible for recent changes in this part of
the code [I think it's best to avoid that except for highly-specific work in
one member's core area of expertise]

text:
*[Bug 18955] cairo library update 1.16 -> 1.18 seems to break font embedding into PDF (R 4.3 -> 4.4 transition)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18955>

--- Comment #9 from Paul Murrell (<mailto:paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz|paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz>) ---
Good news and bad news.  Though both depend on your point of view.

The "bad" news is that I fail to get Ubuntu Condensed embedding via cairo_pdf()
on Windows (R 4.5.1, cairo 1.18.4)

The "good" news is that I can get embedding via cairo_pdf() by using different
fonts, in my case Algerian and Agency FB.

That does not really explain the problem, but it does point the finger back at
the font and/or font installation.

Have you tried with other fonts?
